text: - [Instructor] In this video,
I will explain you

about Amazon CloudWatch Explore
related telemetry feature.

As cloud environments
become increasingly complex

with multiple interconnected
services and resources,
it can be a significant challenge
for IT teams to effectively navigate
and correlate the large volume

of telemetry data generated
across the system.

To address this, Amazon
CloudWatch introduced
the Explore related telemetry feature,
which provides a powerful way

for users to visualize the
relationships between resources

and quickly access the relevant
metrics, logs, and traces.

By leveraging the explore
related telemetry feature,
IT operators, application developers,

and SREs can transform the
observability experience,

gaining deeper insights into
their cloud environments

and accelerating the ability
to resolve complex issues.

Now let's look at the
same in the AWS Console.
Open the AWS Management Console
and navigate to the CloudWatch service.
In the left hand menu, under Insights,
choose Container Insights,
select EKS, and click Explore Related

to view the topology map
and its related metrics.

Click on Workload and select
a workload from the list.

This will display all
the associated metrics
for your selected workload.

To view the topology map
for different services,

click Find Other Resources and
select the desired resource.
In this example,

I am selecting an Amazon ECS
Cluster, Pet List Adoptions.
This will display all the services
that are running within that cluster.
I'll select an ECS service
to view a topology map

that displays all the
connected resources associated
with that specific service,

including the corresponding
metrics and logs.
To explore an Amazon EC2 instance,
click on Find Resources,
and select the EC2 instance,
and click on Apply.
Now select any specific EC2 instance
it displays a topology map
about the specific EC2
and autoscaling group that it belongs to,
and the associated EBS volumes attached
to the specific EC2 instance.

And to view the metrics
associated for an EBS volume,

simply click on the volume ID
displayed in the topology map,
and then it will actually show you

the associated related metrics
for this specific EBS volume.

That's it about the Explore
related telemetry feature.
Thank you.
